title: Managing Business Data in Excel and Tableau
description: This course will introduce fundamental business data management skills and business intelligence tools that are essential for business management. The course will help students to develop basic concepts of data collection and handling, and to know how to structure and solve business problems using Microsoft Excel and Tableau, the most popular and penetrated tool, with the support of Office 365 for Cloud-based communication. Topics such as Storytelling with Tableau, SharePoint, Formulas and Functions, Charts, Subtotals, PivotTables, PivotCharts, What-If Analysis, Specialized Functions, Statistical Functions, Multiple-Sheet Workbook Management, XML, Power Add-Ins, Workbook Distribution, Templates, Styles, and Macros will be covered.

title: Basic Quantitative Methods for Hospitality and Real Estate
description: This course introduces statistical and operation methods appropriate to the hospitality and real estate industry, which include descriptive statistics, probability, correlation and regression, forecasting, decision analysis, quality control, and hotel yield management. Each method will be discussed using examples related to the hospitality and real estate industry.
outcome: This course aims to introduce basic statistical and other analytical tools and concepts that are applicable to decision-making in various business settings. Emphases are on the understanding and application of these concepts. Students are expected to develop their ability to learn independently, and to learn/operate in a group environment. The instructor's role is to organize the learning materials, establish the macro framework of the learning materials/concepts so as to illustrate "the big picture", point out areas of emphasis and alternative considerations, motivate your learning, assist in your understanding of the materials, and assess your learning outcome.
syllabus: • Introduction: Data and Descriptive Measures Basic  • Probability and Discrete Probability Distribution • The Normal Distribution • Sampling Distributions  • Confidence Interval Estimation  • Fundamentals of Hypothesis Testing: One-Sample Tests  • Two-Sample Tests with Numerical Data • Test of Proportions • Tests for Two or More Samples with Categorical Data  • Simple Correlation & Linear Regression
required_readings: Berenson, Levine, and Krehbiel, Basic Business Statistics – Concepts and Applications, Prentice Hall, (International Edition).
recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.

title: Economics for Business Studies I
requirements: Not for students who have taken ECON2011 or ECON3011.
description: This course is a general introduction to the theory of price in a market economy. Topics include basic economic concepts, the theory of demand, production and cost, the operation of firms in competitive, oligopolistic and monopolistic markets, costs and benefits of government intervention in market economy, and introduction to game theory and informational economics. Analytical approach is used whenever appropriate. Applications on practical business problems are emphasized.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to understand, explain and identify the followings:  (1) Basic concepts of scarcity, opportunity cost, demand and supply mechanisms and their applications to the business world. (2) The factors that determine the market demand and their effects by the concept of elasticity. (3) The factors that determine the market supply, the relationship between production function and costs of production. (4) The different market structures (i.e., perfect competition, monopoly and oligopoly) and relate them to the conduct of a firm and performance of the industry. (5) The market failure and their remedies.

title: Basic Economics for the Hospitality and Tourism Industry
description: This course is to provide the students with a basic understanding of the economics of the firm as well as macro-economics. The market forces of demand and supply as well as the firm's price and output decision under various forms of market structure will be analysed. In addition, national income, international trade theory, commercial policies, and foreign exchange market will be treated briefly. Economic applications that are particularly relevant to the hospitality industry will be emphasized.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to: • Develop a basic understanding of demand, supply and elasticity • Explain the basics of the costs of production and market structure • Explain the basics of national income accounting.  • Develop a basic understanding of the determinants of economic growth.  • Explain the determination of saving, investment and the interest rate in the market.  • Explain what money is and what the functions of money are.  • Examine the banking system and the money creation process.  • Distinguish between expected inflation and unexpected inflation and • Describe the real effects of inflation.  • Explain the basic model of aggregate demand and aggregate supply.
syllabus: • Supply and demand • Elasticity • Efficiency and costs of taxation • Government policies • Costs of production • Competitive market • Public goods • The money sector • The real sector • Monetary and Fiscal Policies • Short-run economic trade-off
required_readings: Textbook: Mankiw, N. G. Principles of Economics, Thomson South-Western.
recommended_readings: Bernanke, B., Frank, R. Principles of Economics, McGraw-Hill Irwin. Bade and Parkin, Foundations of Macroeconomics, Addison Wesley.

title: Fundamentals of Business Economics
requirements: Not for students who have taken DSME1030/DOTE1030, DSME1040/DOTE1040 and equivalent courses offered by other departments.
description: This course intends to provide students with fundamentals to the understandings of both micro- and macro-economics for business decision makings and applications. Topics of microeconomics include demand and supply and elasticities, market structure and monopoly power, and the government and its economic functions. Topics of macroeconomics include unemployment, inflation, GDP and long term growth issues, aggregate supply and demand, and fiscal and monetary policies. Other topics of interests can also be included by the course instructor.

title: Economics for Business Studies II
requirements: Not for students who have taken ECON2021 or ECON3021 or UGEC2015
description: This course is a general introduction to the theory of the determination of national income and aggregate economic behaviour. Topics include national income accounting, unemployment, inflation, monetary and fiscal policies for economic stabilization, and international economic issues. Applications of basic macroeconomic principles to contemporary business issues are emphasized.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to understand, explain and apply: (1) Economic variables such as gross national product (GNP), gross domestic product (GDP), consumer price index (CPI), unemployment rate, and economic growth rate. (2) Economic models that explain the business cycles. (3) The role of banking sector, the creation of money, the role of central bank and its impact on monetary policy. (4) The long-run and short-run aggregate supply (AS) and aggregate demand (AD). (5) The role of government and effects of fiscal policy.  (6) The international economy in the context of foreign exchanges and balance of payments (BOP).
syllabus: This course is a general introduction to the theory of the determination of national income and aggregate economic behavior. Topics include national income accounting, unemployment theory, inflation, monetary & fiscal policies for economics stabilization, and international economic issues. Applications of basic macroeconomic principles to contemporary business issues are emphasized.  Course Outline • Measuring a Nation's Income  • Measuring the Cost of Living  • Production and Growth  • Saving, Investment and the Financial System  • The Basic Tools of Finance  • Unemployment  • The Monetary System  • Money Growth and Inflation  • Aggregate Demand (AD) and Aggregate Supply (AS)  • The Influence of Monetary and Fiscal Policy on AD  • The Short-run Tradeoff between Inflation and Unemployment  • Open-Economy Macroeconomics: Basic Concepts  • A Macroeconomic Theory of the Open Economy

title: Statistical Analysis for Business Decisions
requirements: Not for students who have taken ECON2121 or FINA2220 or PSYC2010 or SEEM2430 or STAT2103 or UGEB2471
description: This course deals with the fundamentals of statistical methods, including descriptive statistics, probability, statistical inference, simple linear regression and basic ANOVA. Application of statistical methods to problems pertaining to business will be emphasized throughout this course.

title: Operations Management
requirements: Prerequisite: HTMG1010 or MGNT1010 or 1020.
description: The objective of this course is to provide students with an understanding of how the design, operation, and control of production/operation systems can most effectively produce and/or deliver goods and services to meet customers' needs. Students will be exposed to the problems and issues confronting operations managers in the business world today. Students will also be provided with the language, concepts, insights and tools to address operations management issues. How companies can gain competitive advantage through operations will be discussed. This course will emphasize applications rather than theories. However, the underlying logic of the concepts will be examined so that students can understand the principles upon which their approach is based.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: 1. Understand the roles that Operations Management (OM) plays in a business. Integration of Operations decisions with Marketing and Finance decisions is critical. Students will understand how Operations contributes to the success of the firm; 2. Understand the goals and objectives of OM. We will discuss key decisions and trade-offs involved in effectively managing manufacturing and service operations. 3. Speak the language of OM. Students will be exposed to many special terms and concepts unique to OM; 4. Learn OM techniques that are essential to products/services design, operations process design, management and improvement.
syllabus: • Operations Strategy and Competitiveness • Process Management (Types of Processes, Manufacturing Processes vs. Service Processes, etc.) • Project management • Quality Management (Six Sigma, etc.) • Inventory Management (EOQ, Safety Stock, etc.) • Distribution, Logistics, and ERP system

title: Business Analytics
description: This course will provide a basis for handling and analyzing business data. This course will also give a chance to learn R which is rapidly becoming the default analytics platform as it supports diverse set of analytic tools and statistical methods. This course will present students with real datasets and give opportunities of ‘learning by doing’ through hands-on experience. Specifically, we will study basic concepts in business analytics, and techniques and skills related to data exploration, data utilities, conducting statistical tests, data mining and modeling.

title: Business Information Systems
requirements:

description: This course aims to survey information system technology with an emphasis on the development of computer-based information systems (CBIS). Major topics include: impact of CBIS on management, elements of system development life cycle, data management, transaction processing system, decision support systems, expert systems, and information resources management, etc. Important issues in e-Business such as information technology, security, marketing, finance, and multi-national trade, and practical operation will be discussed.
outcome: After completing this course, students are able to: (1) Understand the basic concepts of information systems and e-commerce. (2) Understand the value of CBIS in business and organization.  (3) Know how to manage data from both external (e.g. business partners) and internal (e.g. functional units) sources. (4) Derive logical design of business applications by using the modeling tools such as ER diagram, Data Flow Diagram, Decision Tree, and Decision Table. (5) Apply practical IT skills acquired from their hands-on projects or cases. (6) Improve their presentation skill and communication skill.

Through case studies, hands-on projects and interactive discussions, students will explore topics such as machine learning, data-driven decision-making, AI ethics and industry-specific applications. title: Behavioral Economics and Business Decisions
requirements: Pre-requisite: DSME1030/DOTE1030 or equivalent course
description: Building on booming evidence in psychology and economics suggesting that individuals' behaviors deviate from the standard economic theory systematically, behavioral economics becomes a fast growing field. In this course, we will provide a broad overview of the modern advances in behavioral economics and the insights gained from incorporating psychology into economic modeling to understand how the psychological factors affect individuals' decision making, and show the business implications of those psychologically richer models, specifically on the strategies of areas including but not limited to consumer decision, investment and competition strategy of the firm, pricing practice, management decision, marketing and advertising, finance and insurance market.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to: (1) Understand and master some basic analytical tools in behavioral economics; (2) Understand an interesting set of insights about the ways that human psychology affects economic decision making; (3) Read and communicate the content of a simple research paper efficiently; (4) Apply the behavioral economic approach to make better business decisions for consumers, competitors, firm managers and governments.

title: Business Forecasting
requirements: Prerequisites: DSME2011/DOTE2011 and DSME2021/DOTE2021.
description: This course provides students with principles and methods in forecasting for managerial planning. Major topics include multiple regression analysis and time series analysis with emphasis on smoothing techniques, decomposition methods, Box-Jenkins procedures, and indicator forecasting. Applications of the methods to both short-term and long-term forecasting to business, industries and national business trends are also emphasized.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to: (1) Understand and use the following forecasting methods: multiple regression analysis, time series analysis (with emphasis on smoothing techniques), decomposition methods, Box-Jenkins procedures, and indicator forecasting (2) Apply the above forecast methods to both short-term and long-term forecasting in business, industries, and national business trends (3) Use various statistical software to perform forecast

title: Corporate Economics
requirements: Prerequisites: (a) DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040 and (b) HTMG1010 or MGNT1020
description: This course provides economic views on the operations of enterprises in a market environment for corporate decision-making and strategy formulation. Students will learn how to analyse market structure and performance, how firms seek competitive advantage, and how industries change. Emphasis will be on the application of economic principles to major business decisions, including pricing, product mix, market entry, mergers, and adoption of new technologies. Industrial policy and its implications will also be discussed.

title: Global Economics
requirements: Prerequisite: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040.
description: The purpose of this course is to equip business students with theory and knowledge of international economics. Both international trade and international macroeconomics will be covered. Applications, especially to current issues, will be emphasized throughout the course.Topics are categorized into three parts: international trade theory and policy, international macroeconomic theory and practice, and applications such as the impact of globalization, and the linked exchange rate in Hong Kong.
outcome: After completing this course, students shall be able to: 1. apply tools in microeconomics to analyze trade issues and their impact to individuals; 2. apply tools in macroeconomics to analyze international macroeconomic issues; 3. understand the importance and implications of globalization; 4. identify proper policy position in international economic issues; 5. read and interpret popular and trade press in business from the perspective of economics.

Project Presentation (Weeks 13-14)

title: Economic Aspects of Business Environment
requirements: Prerequisites: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040, or equivalent courses.
description: This course provides students with an economic perspective of the business environment and equips them with a solid grounding in business economics required for management studies at the university level. The major topics include: economic views of government and business; public choice and regulation; fiscal, monetary, trade and development policies; and the international environment. Examples will be drawn from Hong Kong, PRC in its economic reform since 1979 and the Asian NIE's competitive advantage and trade and industrial policy. Students are expected to exercise initiative in identifying aspects of special interest for in-depth reading. Empirical aspects of economic studies will be stressed through lecturing and case study.

title: Macroeconomics for Managers
requirements: Prerequisites: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040, or equivalent courses.
description: This intermediate-level macroeconomics course is application-oriented and aimed at potential managers. Topics include contemporary aggregate demand and aggregate supply models; money and banking; fiscal and monetary policies on the macro economy and business environments; models of investments; real versus financial investments and evaluation; business cycle theory and sectorial forecasts; and the international linkage and different exchange rate systems. Managerial strategies to the changing business and macroeconomic environments will be emphasized.
outcome: Students would learn the fixed exchange rate version of the Mundell-Fleming model as well as Hong Kong’s economic institution.
syllabus: • Basic measures of the macroeconomy.  • Hong Kong's Trends and Business Cycles.  • Growth.  • The IS-LM model.  • The Balance of Payments and exchange rates.  • The Mundell-Fleming Model.  • The AD-AS Model.

title: Game Theory for Business Strategy
requirements: Prerequisite: DSME1030/DOTE1030
description: This course aims to develop a game theoretic framework for understanding strategies in business. When making managerial decisions, managers must take into account the reactions of rival firms, governments and their subordinates. Game theory offers a systematic way to analyze strategic decision-making process in business, including competition in oligopoly market, contract design, strategic use of information, auction and bargaining.

title: Decision Modeling and Analytics
description: This course introduces the concepts and methods of decision making and analysis, which involves the application of mathematical modeling and analysis to business problems. Models are simplified representations of real situations and can be invaluable tools in decision making. Students will learn the basic elements of modeling-how to formulate a model and how to use and interpret the information a model produces. The emphasis is on models that are widely used in diverse industries and functional areas, including finance, operations, and marketing. Applications include production planning, revenue management, sales force planning, risk management, portfolio optimization, among others. We use spreadsheets and other tools to implement, solve, and analyze the models we develop.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  (1) comprehend basic principles and techniques of applied mathematical modeling for managerial decision-making; (2) structure problems and perform logical analyses; (3) extract insights from the models and use those insights to communicate and motivate changes; (4) grasp spreadsheet skills and tools, including how to design, build, and use a spreadsheet.
syllabus: - Introduction to Spreadsheet Modeling and Problem Solving - Spreadsheet Engineering and Analysis - Modeling and Prototyping - Modeling in Practice - Introduction to Optimization and Solver  - Optimization Models and Sensitivity Analysis - Production Planning, Revenue Management, and Sales Force Sizing and Allocation - Simulation Techniques and Examples - Simulation Modeling and Analysis - Managing Risk with Insurance
required_readings: Management Science: The Art of Modeling with Spreadsheets, by Stephen G. Powell, Kenneth R. Baker
recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.

title: Web Analytics
requirements: Pre-requisite: DSME2011/DOTE2011 and DSME2021/DOTE2021 or permission of instructor.
description: The course focuses on the collection, analysis, and reporting of Internet data for purposes of optimizing web usage and enhancing business decisions. Both online and offline web analytics tools are used for measuring and analyzing web traffic, website performance, and visitor behavior in online commercial settings. Topics covered include web analytics concepts, web analytics technologies and techniques, visitor activity analysis methods, and web intelligence fundamentals.

title: Managerial Economics in the Information Age
requirements: Prerequisites: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040.
description: Managerial Economics combines economic theory and managerial practice, and it is the economic foundation of business analysis and strategy. This course focuses on the application of economic theories and tools to real world management problems and business challenges. Drawing on decision theory, game theory, models of markets and quantitative techniques, the course will apply fundamental concepts of economics to various business decisions, such as demand analysis, production and cost, pricing practices, capital budgeting and risk analysis. Particular attention will be paid to new industries in the information age.

title: Data Management and Big Data Analytics
description: This course focuses on (1) business data requirement analysis, modeling and management; and (2) big data crawling, management system and analytics. The main theme is to capture business applications and requirements, turn them into data models and manage the data using modern database systems. We will also examine methods for capturing, organizing and manipulating big data. Topics such as data integration, big data, DBMS, SQL, Relational model, Entity Relationship model, Data Warehousing, MongoDB, NoSQL and Map/Reduce are covered.
outcome: The role of database systems has extended from being key computing facilities supporting information management into key information resources enabling enterprises to compete in the global marketplace. Modern information technology is now available to facilitate knowledge creation out of existing data sources, codify and store knowledge for subsequent sharing and applications that create value. This course studies the basic methods, models and techniques of data and knowledge management. Specifically, it will achieve the following goals:  1. Discuss database design, processing, and management in the context of relational systems. Topics such as normalization, integrity controls, and query languages (SQL) are emphasized. 2. Develop competence in data modeling. Entity-Relationship models and other semantic data modeling methods are studied and their use for database design is illustrated. 3. Gain hands-on experiences with database systems development using CASE tool and RDBMS. 4. Cover knowledge acquisition, representation and applying knowledge through expert system. 5. Introduce business intelligent that involves discovery knowledge from disparate data sources. Data warehouse, OLAP, data mining and big data are studied.
syllabus: Part I: Database Introductions  - The concept of data integration and the database approach   - Basic file structures in database systems   Part II: Data Modeling  - Relational data model & Normalization schema, integrity rules and implementation   - Structured Query Language  - Semantic data modeling Entity, Relationship and Attributes  Part III: Database Processing and Implementation  - Enterprise modeling: an integrated view using Subject, Context, Entity, and Relationship (Demonstration of a CASE software, IBMS)   - Databases and the Internet ODBC, OLE DB, ADO, & ASP    - Transaction Management, Concurrence Control, and Distributed Database  Part IV: Business Intelligence  - Data Warehousing & Big Data   - Data mining  Part V: Knowledge Based System  - Knowledge acquisition, representation, & reasoning
required_readings: Carlos C., S. Morris, P. Rob, Database Principles: Fundamentals of Design, Implementation and Management, Thomson Publishing Company.
recommended_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.

title: Guided Research in Business Economics
requirements: Prerequisites: DSME1030/DOTE1030 and DSME1040/DOTE1040.
description: The course allows students to investigate in depth a topic of business economics issues under close direction of a teacher. The topics include important macroeconomic issues and policies related to business operation, economy industry analysis, corporate strategies and trend forecasting in a particular industry, and governmental industrial policies and regulations. The course also covers essential skills in research, report writing and presentation.

title: Economic Analytics
requirements: Prerequisite: DSME1030/DOTE1030
description: This course aims to provide economic views on the operations of enterprises for understanding corporate decision making and strategy formulation. The course is linked to game theory, the theory of the firm and industrial organization, and information economics. In particular, emphasis will be placed on the application of economic principles to major business decisions, including pricing, market entry and exit, strategic use of information and contract design. Industry analysis and governmental regulation will also be discussed.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:  (1) demonstrate understanding of what corporate strategies; (2) use economic theory to analyze issues in strategic management under different market structure; (3) appreciate the importance of corporate strategic decisions; (4) evaluate the role of game theoretic approaches to strategic choices;  (5) understand the challenges and opportunities of a firm under globalizations.
syllabus: • Game Theoretic Analysis • Competition in Oligopoly Market • Firm Boundaries • Entry and Exit • Asymmetric Information: Screening and Signaling • Contract Design: Principal-Agent Problem and Incentive Alignment • Industry Analysis • Regulation

recommended_readings: Baye, Managerial Economics and Business Strategy, McGraw Hill. Perloff, Microeconomics, Pearson Prentice Hall. Dixit, Skeath, and Reiley, Games of Strategy, W. W. Norton & Company. Osborne, An introduction to game theory, Oxford University Press. McMillan, Games, Strategies, and Managers, Oxford University Press.

title: Selected Topics of Decisions, Operations and Technology
description: This course is designed to investigate and to discuss selected topics of current interests in the area of business/managerial economic and/or decision science analysis.

title: Information Systems Analysis and Design
requirements: Prerequisite: DSME2051/DOTE2051 or permission of instructor.
description: This course aims to introduce to students various activities associated with the development of business information systems. Students will learn to analyse information requirements and to design appropriate solutions that lead to sophisticated business systems. The concepts of system development life cycle (SDLC) and human- computer interaction will be introduced. Various methodologies, such as structured- and object-oriented analysis and design, will be emphasized. An introduction on how to use a CASE tool to help developing business information systems will also be given.

title: Data Communications and Networking
requirements: Prerequisite: DSME2051/DOTE2051 or permission of instructor.
description: This course introduces data communications concepts, components, architecture, protocols, and standards for message movement within a network. Both the technical and managerial aspects of designing, controlling, and managing networks in the distributed environment will be emphasized.

title: Financial Information Technology
requirements: Prerequisite: DSME2051/DOTE2051 or permission of instructor.
description: This course examines the use of information technology and systems in financial services and investment management. Topics covered include neural network, fuzzy logic, data mining and decision technologies relevant to financial services. Students will also learn to use Excel VBA to develop financial application systems.

title: Global Logistics Management
description: This course will examine the integrative role of logistics within the supply chain and look at logistics services from the perspective of logistic service providers. The general concepts and importance of global logistics management will be a major focus. We will provide students with an overall understanding of various activities handled by logistic service providers. Through problem-solving scenarios, projects and case studies, we will cover concepts, practical tools, and effective practices in logistics management. Topics include: introduction to the logistics functions and logistics industries, distribution strategies, warehousing and transportation management, design of the logistics networks, purchasing and outsourcing, and logistics information systems.

title: Global Supply Chain Management
description: This course will examine the strategic role of supply chain management in global competition. We provide students with the concepts, decision models and practical tools necessary for effective decision-making in the various areas of supply chain. Through problem solving and case studies, the course will develop students’ intuition behind many key supply chain concepts and practices. We will demonstrate how cost reduction, productivity improvement, flexibility, speed, and customer satisfaction can be achieved through supply chain enhancement. Topics include: the strategic framework for supply chain management, planning the demand and supply in a supply chain, planning and managing inventories in a supply chain, information technology management and information sharing in a supply chain, strategic alliances and coordination.

title: Business Web Design and Authoring
description: This course provides students with the basic knowledge required for designing and developing state-of-the-art interactive sites in the WWW. The primary focus will be on using Java Applets and JSP Web server pages to create Web business applications that can handle user requests and activate the relevant business processes. As the power of Web business applications relies heavily on access to the content of available databases, this course will also explore the technologies that have gained wide attention in the business information technology sectors, such as Java Database Connectivity (JDBC) and the Extensible Markup Language (XML). No prior programming knowledge is required.

title: Data Mining for Business Intelligence
requirements: Pre-requisite: DSME2011/DOTE2011 and DSME2021/DOTE2021 or DSME2011/DOTE2011 and DSME2040/DOTE2040 or permission of instructor.
description: This course will focus on data analysis and decision making in organization and across organizational boundaries. Learn how to use Business Intelligence (BI) tools to produce the valuable information to decision makers in the organization. This course will also introduce the fundamental data mining techniques (e.g. classification, clustering, market basket). Student will learn how to capture the right knowledge, providing it to the right user at the right time.
outcome: The student will acquire knowledge and experience of: • understand the knowledge cycle; • understand day-to-day business transaction/ operation; • use Business Intelligence Tools to analyze business operations and produce information to help business users understand, improve and optimize business operations; • how to collaborate with other business units.
syllabus: • Introduction to business intelligence • Introduction to Business intelligence architectures  - A data warehouse  - Business analytics  - Business performance management • Introduction to major business intelligence tools  - Data preparation  - Decision support systems  - Data warehouse  - Data mining • Introduction to Data Mining Methods   - Prediction  - Association  - Clustering • Introduction to Data Mining Applications
required_readings: (1) Data Mining: A tutorial –based Primer, Pearson Education (2) Business Intelligence: A Managerial Approach, Prentice Hall
recommended_readings: To be arranged by course teacher.

title: Information Systems Practicum
description: This course bridges the gap between classroom and real world. It requires students to complete a real-world information systems project, in collaboration with a company or organization. A minimum of three and a maximum of five students are required to form a project team, under the joint supervision of a MIS faculty member and a senior executive of the sponsoring company.

title: Supply Chain and Logistics Analytics
description: This course first reviews the fundamentals of supply chain management and logistics management, and then examines how business analytics can be used to improve the competitiveness of supply chains and logistics processes. We will discuss the strategic role of supply chain management in global competition and the effective decision-making in the various areas of supply chain. The integrative role of logistics within the supply chain and the many logistics issues confronting logistic service providers will be examined. We will explore applying such analytics as data mining, forecasting, and optimization on demand planning, supply chain planning, and logistics planning. Business analytics can be used to predict and diagnose managerial problems in supply chain and logistics management, tracking most profitable products, identifying product quality issues, and better forecasting raw material needs.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to: 1. understand the roles that supply chains play in a global economy and how supply chain work and contribute to the success of the firm; 2. understand the economic impacts and significance of global logistics management; 3. learn technical material on inventory theory, risk pooling, and transportation optimization;  4. apply business analytics to solve supply chain and logistics management problems.

required_readings: Marshall Fisher and Ananth Raman, The New Science of Retailing: How Analytics are Transforming the Supply Chain and Improving Performance, Harvard Business Press.  Gerald Feigin, Supply Chain Planning and Analytics: The Right Product in the Right Place at the Right Time, Business Expert Press.

title: Business Process Analytics
description: This course aims to enhance the knowledge and skills related to business process management and improvement, with an emphasis on the applications of analysis and simulation tools. A simulation package will be introduced and will be used to evaluate business process performance and identify possibility of process improvement. The knowledge learnt from the course can help improve scientific competence to deal with practical problems in various settings related to business process management.
outcome: The student will acquire knowledge and experience of: (1) understand and use the basic languages and tools of business process management; (2) master fundamental relationships in business processes, in particular the Little's Law; (3) recognize how, when, and why scientific tools for business process management can be used; (4) understand the context of a business process problem, and to apply analysis and simulation to model the problem and to make improvement decisions; (5) have working knowledge of iGrafx (or other simulation software) in terms of business process simulation.
syllabus: • Product attributes and business process management • Process flow measures and analysis • Managing process variability and quality • Process synchronization and improvement
required_readings: "Managing Business Process Flows", by Ravi Anupindi, Sunil Chopra, Sudhakar D. Deshmukh, Jan A. Van Mieghem, and Eitan Zemel, Pearson Prentice Hall.

title: Current and Regional Issues in Supply Chain and Logistics Management
description: This course provides an overview of the current issues in supply chain and logistics management that are of special relevance to Hong Kong and mainland China. Hong Kong, a gateway (for Pearl River Delta) and a transshipment hub (for mainland China and other parts of Asia), houses many local and international logistics service providers. In this course, we examine the regional logistics industries that are of special relevance to Hong Kong and mainland China, as well as their principal agents. These agents include freight forwarders, warehousing operators, airlines, terminal operators, integrators, trucking operators, customs and electronic agents, etc. We will discuss the respective roles of these agents in the management of logistics within a supply chain. Recent trends in trade, distribution, and adoption of IT for cargo logistics are covered.

title: Network and Security
description: This course is a survey of the concepts and principles of data communications and networks. It also provides an introduction to the field of information security, covering its management, technology, and practice. Topics include transmission and media, network and security protocols, network security and management, cryptography, and access control.
outcome: • Master the fundamental terminology, concepts, and principles of data communication, computer networks, and information security; • Understand the application/impact/issues/security/practices of networking and data communications in common business applications and management; • Make intelligent and reasonable decisions about the optimal configuration, installation, and operation of a data communication network; • Able to apply information security technologies and strategies to protect an organization’s data resources.
syllabus: Topics include transmission and media, network and security protocols, network security and management, cryptography, and access control.
required_readings: To be assigned by course teacher.
recommended_readings: • Stallings, W. and Case, T. Business Data Communications, Pearson.  • Stallings, W. and Brown, L. Computer Security: Principles and Practices, Pearson.

title: Microeconomic Theory
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Accountancy; or MPhil-PhD Business Administration; or MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology; or MPhil-PhD Finance; or MPhil-PhD Marketing
description: This course is on advanced microeconomic theory. Topics include individual decision theory (consumer theory, production theory, choice under uncertainty), game theory (static and dynamic games under complete and incomplete information), and equilibrium and market failure (general equilibrium, principal-agent problems, economics of information, auctions, bargaining, and market design).
outcome: After completing this course, students are expected to:1. acquire a solid foundation advanced microeconomic theory and related applications;2. master model solving skills for more advanced studies in theory and applied fields;3. apply techniques of economic modeling in the context of a business problem.

title: Macroeconomics in a Globalized Era
requirements: For students in EMBA
description: The course begins by constructing a simplified model of the macro economy. This is intended to help organize your discussion of issues confronting an economy. Every opportunity is taken to reinforce the economic concepts with current data, particularly for the U.S. and China. We then proceed to examine the policy instruments used to steer an economy towards the objectives of sustainable growth, stable inflation and low unemployment. Broadly speaking, these policy tools are monetary policy, implemented by a country's central bank, and fiscal policy implemented by the government when it makes expenditure and taxation decisions. We extend our exposition of traditional monetary policy to explain the Federal Reserve's quantitative easing, as well as the essential factors contributing to the financial crisis which necessitated this unconventional monetary policy. We then move onto the interactions between economies as captured in their respective balance of payment accounts and exchange rate movements. Fluctuations in China's RMB will be closely analyzed at this point and open the door for an in-depth look into China's domestic imbalances. We also examine Hong Kong's unique currency board system under-pinning our linked exchange rate.
outcome: Students should be able to critically analyze current macroeconomic issues, both domestic and global, and formulate solutions to economic challenges and problems.

Changes in the Money Supply - The Multiplier Process5. Monetary Policy6. Fiscal Policy7. Open-Economy Macroeconomics - Basic Concepts8. Hong Kong's Currency Board

The international economy in the context of foreign exchanges and balance of payments (BOP).

title: Business Analytics
requirements: For students in EMBA; or EMBA (Chinese)
description: The major objective of this course is to provide students with real life examples of the application of quantitative methods, such as business statistics and operations research, to help business executives solve problems in competitive business environments.
outcome: The major objective of this course is to provide students with basic understanding on the most important quantitative techniques used in business analysis. Although the course is quantitative in nature, we will try to avoid dealing with complicated mathematical theories whenever possible and, instead, stress on the intuition and logic behind the mathematical models and their managerial implications. Except for some illustrative examples in which problems may be solved manually, we will make heavy use of the popular Microsoft Excel and some of its add-in programs (e.g., Solver and StatTools) to solve most of the problems. It is our hope that, by the end of the term, you will feel comfortable about using Excel to analyse data and solve many of your business problems. More importantly, after completing this course, we hope you will develop a habit of thinking your problems in logical ways.

title: Strategic Value of Innovation and Technology
requirements: For students in EMBA
description: As an organization gets bigger and more mature, there is a tendency to soften up on the original entrepreneurial and innovative culture. In the digital economy, competitors are coming from not just the same industry but also innovative tech giants and start-ups. The need for faster change and continued growth can only be met with increased flexibility, agility and innovation. Corporate leaders need to think and act like entrepreneurs to stay relevant and competitive in the Digital Economy. Fortunately, innovation and entrepreneurship are not just for tech giants and start-ups. They can be learned. This course is designed for business leaders and professionals to acquire an even greater level of entrepreneurial, innovative and agile mindset and capabilities as the ultimate source of competitive advantage.
outcome: This course aims to empower students to leverage on innovation and technology to create values to their companies, customers and key stakeholder.  The students will also learn how to make challenging decisions in a corporate innovation and entrepreneurial environment.Upon completion of the course, the participants are expected to be able to:A. Develop an innovation strategy that aligns with the corporate strategyB. Manage innovation as a scienceC. Master the key success factors for corporate innovationD. Learn the best practices of innovation from successful entrepreneurs and cultivate intrapreneursE. Collaborate and engage with open innovation ecosystems for value co-creation
syllabus: 1. Old Economy Vs Digital Economy- Apart from the companies in your same industry, who else are your major competitors?   - Why do we need to care or even worry about these competitors?- What can we learn from these new competitors or disruptors?2. Innovation Vs Customer Centricity- What is the most critical success factor for leaders in the Digital Economy?- How does customer centricity relate to innovation?- How important is “Empathy” for our innovation?3. Execution for Strategy Vs Search for Innovation- How can we formulate an innovation strategy aligned with business strategy?- Can innovation be managed like a science?- What are the best practices to generate, cultivate and scale ideas to empower innovation?- What is an innovation strategy?  To be more precise, what is a great innovation strategy?- How can we align our company on clear innovation objectives?- How can we focus on our traditional business and innovation at the same time?- How to create a culture of innovation?- How should we innovate like leading tech companies?4. Internal Innovation Vs External Collaboration- What are the limitations of Internal Innovation?- What is an ecosystem?  What stakeholders are in the ecosystem?  - Why should we engage with the ecosystem?  How can we leverage on the ecosystem? - What are the challenges in collaborating with the ecosystem and how do we resolve them?5. Entrepreneurship Vs Intrapreneurship - Why “Entrepreneurship” is getting more and more critical for corporate innovation?- What is Intrapreneurship?  What are the major similarities and differences between entrepreneurs and intrapreneurs?- How do corporate leaders nurture intrapreneurship in their companies?  What are the key challenges to cultivate intrapreneurs in corporates?6. Experience-driven Vs Data-driven- Why do today’s enterprises need to be data-driven? - What are the key benefits of being a data-driven enterprise?- What are the shortfalls of experience-driven management?- What is data-driven culture?  Why is it important?- How do you nurture data culture in your company?  What are the major challenges?  How do you resolve these challenges?

title: Econometric Theory and Applications
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Accountancy; or MPhil-PhD Business Administration; or MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology; or MPhil-PhD Finance; or MPhil-PhD Marketing
description: This course is designed for business Ph.D. students who need to apply econometrics in their research. The major contents of this course will focus on two parts. The first part will cover fundamental econometrics topics such as ordinary least squares, instrumental variable estimation, panel data models, and generalized linear model. The second part will cover topics about business causal inference by either randomized field/lab experiments or natural experiments such as matching, difference-in-differences, and regression discontinuity design. This course is a graduate econometrics course that emphasizes application in pratice. Knowledge of multivariate calculus, linear algebra, statistics, and econometrics at the undergraduate level is preferred.
outcome: After completing this course, students can:• Understand the basic approaches in econometrics such as OLS, IV, and GLM• Design a randomized experiment and test certain treatment effects• Use natural experiment to identify the causal effect of a business policy• Know how to apply econometrics with frequently-used software such as Stata and computer languages such as R• Improve their data analysis skills

title: Business Analytics and Digital Innovation
requirements: For students in MSc in Management
description: This course will explore how business data and big data play a key role in business model, service as well as process innovations. The unique ramifications of mastering the technical and managerial aspects of business analytics that lead to digital innovations will be discussed. The course will not only survey the latest enabling technologies and their applications in business management but also provide a holistic overview of the data analytics models and tools. Emphases are placed on understanding of intuitions behind these tools as well as their applications in various areas of management, including marketing, finance and operations.

title: Managing Service Operations

description: This course is designed for students to learn the latest theories, frameworks, concepts, techniques and to apply them in meeting the special challenges of managing service operations. The focus is to develop analytical thinking skills that will enable students contemplating careers in services to develop, evaluate and implement strategies for a wide range of service producing organizations. Topics will include: 1). the importance and economics of customer loyalty and approaches to build customer loyalty; 2). formulation and implementation of service strategies and the strategic service vision for greater business success; 3). management of the operational behavior of customers in service delivery; 4). design of sustainable service models that successfully incorporate a customer’s operating role; 5). analyses of customer data to inform managerial decision making; and 6). management of changes in service settings.

title: Supply Chain Sustainability Management
requirements: For students in MSc in Sustainable Global Business

title: Financial Data Modeling and Analysis
requirements: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)

It shows students how to apply such techniques in the context of finance. Time-series analyses aim to explain the important influence of time-dependence in making economical predictions. title: Macro and Micro Economics
requirements: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
description: This course is to provide students with basic understanding of modern economics of the firm and of the economy as a whole. The market forces of demand and supply as well as the firm’s price and output decisions under various forms of market structure will be analysed. Issues related to regulation and competition on the market will be studied. At the macro level, topics such as national income and its determination, international trade theory and commercial policies, the foreign exchange market, and the balance of international payments will be discussed.

title: Modelling Methodology in Management Science
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology
description: This course introduces students to some basic issues in the design and completion of a research project in business and economics. These issues include the initial choice of a research problem, the use of quantitative vs. qualitative methods for undertaking that research, potential pitfalls that may be met along the way, and the presentation of results in a scholarly manuscript. Fundamental modelling methodologies will also be covered.

title: Platform and Business Strategies
requirements: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
description: Success in business needs strategies. The advances of information technology have given business strategies a new dimension: building computer-mediated networks to facilitate transactions over e-platforms. The examples include Amazon, Google, Spotify, iTunes, Alibaba, Uber, Airbnb, and many other B2B, B2C, and C2C platforms. The e-platform business has network effect following demand-side scale economies that sees the value of a product from the willingness-to-pay of customers. This creates new perspectives of business strategies on pricing, platform products, envelopment attacks, winner-takes-all effect, and cannibalization. This course discusses how to run a successful business with e-platforms.
outcome: On successful completion of this course, students should be able to: 1) be familiar with major managerial issues in Internet business,  2) understand how to run a platform business, and  3) be familiar with the competition strategies in Internet platform business.
syllabus: 1. Platform Business 2. The Network Effect 3. Products and Platforms 4. Pricing Strategies 5. Adopting Strategies with Network Effect  6. Winner-Takes-All Market 7. Redefining the Market: The Envelopment Attack 8. Going to the Market: First Mover Disadvantage? 9. Going to the Market: Cannibalization

title: Research Methods in Microeconomics
requirements: For students in MPhil/PhD Decision Sciences and Managerial Economics or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology
description: This course is a combination of two separate mini-courses.In the first half of the course we take a microeconomic perspective to analyze a number of important resource-allocating systems that are widely used in real life, including auctions, matching mechanisms, and trading platforms for financial assets. For each system we study its objective, structure, and actual performance. We will focus on the theoretical aspects of these systems, but will also examine empirical findings on how well they function. The second half of course surveys modern methods of applied micro-econometric research. We will begin by reviewing the Rubin Causal Model, its relationship with structural models, and the econometric definition of identification. We will then proceed to consider a number of econometric estimators, research designs, and inferential methods.

title: Data Visualization and Business Intelligence
requirements: For students in MBA; or JD/MBA Double Degree Programme
description: In the increasingly competitive world, the need for timely analysis of constantly expanding data to gain business intelligence and communication of the results to the key decision makers has become a vital part of a company’s operation. In the past, business intelligence used to be in the domain of IT specialists. With the advent of self-service data visualization and business intelligence tools, such as Excel BI toolkit, now anyone with adequate training can produce their own analyses with minimal support from central IT. The aim of this course is to introduce to students the Excel BI toolkit that has become an integral part of Excel since Excel 2013. Designed to handle very large amount of data, the toolkit consists of four add-ins, namely, Power Query, Power Pivot, Power View, and Power Map. Students will learn how to use these add-ins to gain business intelligence. Students who are interested in taking this course are expected to have at least intermediate level and preferably advanced level of Excel skills.

title: Multivariate Statistics
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology
description: This course provides students with the basic multivariate analysis principles, techniques, and applications based on statistics theory. Major topics include factor analysis, multiple discriminant analysis, multivariate analysis of variance, cluster analysis, principle component analysis, etc. The techniques introduced will be useful in conducting quantitative research in various areas in business and economics including management, marketing, and management information system. Applications of the techniques to real – world economic and business problems will be emphasized. Statistical software will also be introduced to familiarize students with the application of multivariate analysis techniques in their research.

title: Economics of Information Systems
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology
description: The use of economics as a reference discipline for IS research has gained significant recognition over the past twenty years. This course is designed to introduce the research stream (as known as Economics of IS) to Ph.D. students with economic theories, models, and methodologies used in IS research. Specifically, this course deals with classical research questions, methods, and findings which form the backbone of Economics of IS. In addition, the course extends its focus and also covers the growing field of behavioral economics and its connection with IS research. Although the course relies primarily on IS literature, it is appropriate for Ph.D. students with a variety of backgrounds including Information Systems, Operations Management, Strategy, Marketing, and Economics.

title: Advanced BE Research Seminar
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology
description: This seminar course provides students with a broad exposure to research in Business Economics (BE). It will cover the development of current research topics such as game theory, information economics, firm and contract theory, industrial organization, and other topics related to microeconomics. Students are expected to read assigned papers thoroughly prior to classes and be able to discuss the paper's key assumptions and how those assumptions influence the paper;s key findings. The contribution of the papers to the literature will also be discussed.

title: Decision Models and Applications
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc Business Analytics
description: This course covers the principal quantitative techniques used in solving financial, marketing, and operations problems in the private and public sectors. Topics include decision under uncertainty, Markov chain, linear programming, classical optimization, dynamic programming, and integer programming.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:(1) master a range of fundamental quantitative techniques for decision making;(2) have working knowledge of software packages (such as Excel) for decision making;(3) apply the quantitative techniques to modeling and solving decision making problems in various fields including finance, marketing, and operations.

title: Advanced MIS Research Seminar
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology
description: This course provides students with a broad-based exposure to research in MIS and its research methodologies, including survey, case study, experimental design, and field work. Various theories used in MIS research will also be discussed to provide students with background on approaches to theory building and theory testing. Seminal MIS articles will be reviewed to orient students to the emergence of MIS discipline and its research tradition and trend.
outcome: 1. Possess relevant knowledge and skills in academic research 2. Able to propose intelligent and insightful research questions, along with their proposed research methods  3. Understand and able to apply varied research methodologies and techniques to MIS research 4. Possess the ability and experience in critiquing academic research works 5. Able to prepare and present IS research proposals for research grants
syllabus: Markets, organizations, and individuals use a wide variety of structures to co-ordinate resource production and allocation. Dramatic changes in information technology (IT) and business activities are forcing firms to come up with new ways of organizing work. Similarly, new types of digital information goods, much lower search costs, innovative ways of doing marketing, management, finance and human resource all lead to the disruption of old business models and creation of new ones.This course uses economic theory to investigate the roles of information and technology in the existing diversity of organizations and markets and in enabling the creating of new organizational forms. The class is designed for PhD students in management, economics, information technology, marketing, operations management, organizational behavior and related disciplines. For economists, this class offers the opportunity to apply economic tools to understand how information technology and information in general affect organizations and markets. For non-economists, this class offers an exposure to fundamental ideas in the economics of information, organizations, and markets. This course covers quantitative research methodologies in Economics of IS. It consists of three components: Methodology, Economics of IS Research Topics, and Writing and Publishing. The main goal is to prepare PhD students to produce publication quality research using tools from information economics.We will cultivate a culture of collaborative learning. In particular, in this seminar class, students come prepared to engage in thoughtful discussions of the materials. Students are asked to write informal, short memos prior to several of the classes. These memos will generally be responses to some questions or issues we pose prior to each class. In addition, each student will be asked to present at least one of the research papers as part of the class discussion.

title: Research Sem in Operations & SCM

Students will be required to read research papers, critique and synthesize other people's research work, and identify areas for future research. They are also required to present and discuss other people's research and their own research proposals. The instructor and scholars from different universities will also be invited to present their latest research. Topical areas will include Operations Supply Chain Strategy, Total Quality Management, Service Operations Management, Innovation and New Product Development, Lean Thinking, Business Process Improvement/Innovation, Relationship Management and Supply Chain Integration, Supply Chain/Logistics Network Design and other topics.

title: Artificial Intelligence for Business Research
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Accountancy; or MPhil-PhD Business Administration; or MPhil-PhD Decision Sciences & Managerial Economics; or MPhil-PhD Decisions, Operations and Technology; or MPhil-PhD Finance; or MPhil-PhD Marketing
description: Modern artificial intelligence (AI) has largely reshaped our world over the past 10 years. This course is designed to prepare students from a broad range of business areas (e.g. Finance, Marketing, Accounting, Management, Operations, Information Systems, Business Economics, Hotel Management etc.) for the cutting-edge research that connects AI and business. At a high-level, students taking this course will learn the followings:• Fundamental concepts/methods of machine learning (ML) and AI that are used in business research ;• How business researchers have utilized ML/AI and what managerial questions have been addressed by ML/AI in the past several years ;• The huge mismatch between AI technologies and the adoption of AI technologies in our fields.
outcome: The students taking this course will receive multi-faceted training in AI for business research. At the end of this course, their expected learning outcomes are summarized as follows: Reasonable mastery of the fundamental ideas and tools in AI (and their limitations) that are widely used in their research field; Understanding the state-of-the-art literature landscape and research norm for the interface between AI and business; Being able to apply AI techniques in their own research; Being able to identify new research questions in their field that are potentially solvable by AI techniques.
syllabus: Topics to CoverWe will cover the following 5 main topics related to the interface between AI and business research in this course:·       Fundamental concepts and hands-on techniques of ML, deep learning (DL), and reinforcement learning (RL) that are useful in business research ;·       AI as data sources (e.g., demand and asset return predictions, feature and label extractions from unstructured text, image, and video data, etc.) to address subsequent relevant business research questions ;·       AI/ML applied to causal models for better identification and/or inference of treatment effects with both observational and experimental data (e.g., double/de-biased machine learning DML, causal trees/forests, matrix completion, doubly-robust estimation, etc.) ;·       AI for optimizing certain business operations in an autonomous and efficient fashion (e.g., online optimization, multi-armed bandit, reinforcement learning, imitation learning, etc.) ;·       AI per se as a subject of study in business research, such as human-algorithm interaction, algorithmic fairness/discrimination, and data privacy, etc.

title: Economic Analytics
requirements: For students in MSc Business Analytics
description: This course is about applying economic models with data to deal with corporate decisions and strategies. The art and science of economic modeling for this purpose makes use of the principles and the tools derived from the studies of information economics, games, industrial organization and the related fields. The course is conducted in a variety of formats including lectures, cases studies and other activities. Operation and strategic issues covered in the course include setting prices, designing contracts, managing firm boundaries, controlling strategic information, analyzing entry and exit, and formulating competitive strategy.

description: Blockchain technology provides a dynamic shared ledger that enables peer-to-peer transfer of digital assets without any intermediaries, and is predicted to be a revolutionary technology that is just as impactful as the Internet. title: Mobile and Web Applications Development

Students will work directly with the Java programming language and the latest Android developer tools, with the goal of enabling students to produce fully functional prototypes independently. title: Cyber Security
requirements: For students in MSc in Information & Technology Management
description: This course provides an overview of the threats to networked organizations. Students will learn and understand the key issues associated with cyber space security, skills required to respond to security incidents, and knowledge needed to design security systems and protect security intrusions. Its coverage includes a variety of concepts and topics related to the securing of networked, cloud, and mobile processing environments.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to: (1) assess the current security landscape and the likely consequences of security failures; (2) apply the practices, technologies, and protocols of cyber security to secure business operations; (3) assess the security challenges in the virtual, cloud, and mobile processing environments; (4) understand the legal, ethical, and regulatory issues associated with cyber security policy development, implementation, and administration.
syllabus: Possible topics include: • Physical and system security (such as access control, user authentication, malicious software, and operating system security) • Network security (such as encryption, intrusion detection and prevention, and firewalls) • Security protocols and standards • Database and cloud computing security • Wireless security • Security management and planning  • Legal and ethical aspects of security

title: Supply Chain and Logistics Management

description: This course covers the concepts, insights, practical tools, and decision support systems for the effective management of the supply chain. title: Strategy and Innovation Management
requirements: For students in EMBA (Chinese)
description: The aim of this course is to provide a solid grounding to students interested in managing various aspects of the innovation process and understanding it better from a policy perspective. The course is divided into two parts. Broadly, the first two-thirds of the course focuses more on analytic and strategic frameworks for managing innovation. This segment examines patterns of technological change and their impacts, planning for technological transitions, means for capturing economic benefits from innovation, and planning of innovation projects over time. The last third of the course examines more organizational issues involved in implementing strategies. These issues include management of teams and partnerships, learning within and across projects, the manager's role in forecasting and funding, directing and stopping innovation projects, technological entrepreneurship, and barriers to innovation. Case studies, both written and video-based, are used extensively to illustrate a range of technologies and the problems associated with developing them and bringing them to market.

title: Enterprise Resource Planning
requirements: For students in MSc Information & Technology Management; or MSc in Info Sci and Tech Mgt
description: Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) is an integrated information technology to manage company-wide business processes. The topics include two aspects: enterprise resource planning system and the ERP project implementation issues. This course will also introduce the evolution of ERP, concepts and applications of ERP. The topics of enterprise systems will mainly brief on the core modules along the value chain such as product development, order fulfillment, production and others. Finally, the "ERP and beyond" will address how the latest developments of ERP can be extended to fulfill the new demand of more enterprise initiatives. Students will be requested to work on a group project.
outcome: After completing the course, the students are expected to1. comprehend the concept / theory of enterprise resource planning2. be familiar with an enterprise system, particularly the ERP suite3. understand the issues for an ERP implementation4. apprehend the future trends of ERP

title: Information Technology and Electronic Commerce
requirements: For students in MBA in Finance (40087); or MBA in Finance (40324)
description: The course provides an overview of the technologies that support the development of e-Commerce applications, business models and strategies for e-Commerce, electronic payments and security, and legal issues related to e-Commerce such as intellectual property rights. In particular it covers various methods of transferring payments over the Internet and compares their functionality. Electronic cash, electronic checks, electronic credit cards, micro-payments, the encryption and digital signature techniques needed to support electronic cash, and the technologies available to support secure transactions on the Internet will be discussed. Implementations of various payment systems are examined.
